revision.text:
{{unreliable sources|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = William Frawley | image =William Frawley 1951.JPG | imagesize = 225px | caption =Frawley in 1951, shortly before he assumed the role of Fred Mertz on ''I Love Lucy''. | birth_name = William Clement Frawley | birth_date = {{Birth date|1887|2|26|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Burlington, Iowa]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1966|3|3|1887|2|26|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | resting_place = [[San Fernando Mission Cemetery]] | occupation = Actor | alias = Bill Frawley | years_active = 1916–1965 | spouse = {{marriage|Edna Louise Broedt|1914|1927|end=divorced}} }}
'''William Clement Frawley''' (February 26, 1887 – March 3, 1966) was an American stage entertainer and screen and television actor best known for playing landlord [[Fred Mertz]] in the famous American [[Sitcom|television sitcom]] ''[[I Love Lucy]]'' and Bub in the television comedy series ''[[My Three Sons]]''.
Frawley began his career in [[vaudeville]] in 1914 with his wife, Edna Louise Broedt. Their comedy act, known as "Frawley and Louise", continued until their divorce in 1927. Frawley performed on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] multiple times and signed with [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount Studios]] in 1916 to play in [[silent film]]s. He appeared in more than one hundred films over 35 years.<ref name=":0">Deezen, Eddie. {{Cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/30088/being-fred-mertz-life-william-frawley|title=Being Fred Mertz: The Life of William Frawley|website=Mental Floss|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref>
==Early life== William Clement Frawley was born of Irish ancestry in 1887 in [[Burlington, Iowa]], the second son of four children of Michael A. Frawley (1857–1907) and Mary E. (Brady) Frawley (1859–1921). He attended [[Catholic school]]s and sang in the choir at St. Paul's Catholic Church. As he got older, he played small roles in local theater productions at the Burlington Opera House as well as performed in amateur shows, though his mother, a highly religious woman, discouraged such activities.<ref name=":0"/>
Frawley's first job was as a [[Stenographer|stenographer]] in an office of the [[Union Pacific Railroad]] in [[Omaha, Nebraska]].<ref name=":0"/> After two years working in that position, he relocated to Chicago, where he found a job as a [[court reporter]]. Not long after that move, and against his mother's wishes, he obtained a singing part in a [[musical comedy]], ''The Flirting Princess''. To appease his mother, Frawley relocated to [[St. Louis, Missouri]], to work for another railroad company.<ref>{{cite web|author=Chris JH|title=William Frawley: A Biography|publisher=Lucy & Company|url=http://members.aol.com/beedow1/william.htm|accessdate=2007-06-14}}</ref>
Feeling unfulfilled in that job as well, he continued to hope he would one day be a professional entertainer. He finally decided to act on that desire by forming a [[vaudeville]] act with his brother Paul (1889–1973), but six months later Frawley's mother told Paul to return to Iowa. Meanwhile, William wrote and sold a script titled ''Fun in a Vaudeville Agency'', earning more than $500 for his efforts. {{cn|date=March 2018}}
After his initial success as a scriptwriter, Frawley decided to relocate yet again, this time to the [[Western United States|West]], settling in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]], where he was hired as a singer at a café and teamed with [[pianist]] Franz Rath. The duo soon moved to [[San Francisco]] with their act, "A Man, a Piano, and a Nut". During his vaudeville career, Frawley introduced and helped popularize the songs "[[My Mammy]]",<ref>{{cite web|title=Al Jolson "The Jazz Singer"|publisher = ParlorSongs Association, Inc. (ParlorSongs.com)|url=http://parlorsongs.com/bios/aljolson/aljolson.asp|accessdate=2007-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630122718/http://parlorsongs.com/bios/aljolson/aljolson.asp|archivedate=2007-06-30}}</ref> "[[My Melancholy Baby]]", and "[[Carolina in the Morning]]". Many years later, in 1958, he recorded a selection of his old stage songs on an [[LP album|LP]], ''Bill Frawley Sings the Old Ones''.<ref>{{cite web|author = George Gimarc & Pat Reeder|title=Bill Frawley aka Fred Mertz ("I Love Lucy")|work=SITCOM SERENADERS|publisher=gimarc.com – Excerpted from ''Hollywood Hi-Fi''|url=http://www.gimarc.com/H-frawley.html|accessdate=2007-06-15}}</ref>
==Early career== [[File:Something to Sing About Cagney Frawley Windheim.jpg|thumb|left|With [[James Cagney]] in ''[[Something to Sing About (1937 film)|Something to Sing About]]'']] Frawley began performing in [[Broadway theater]]. His first such show was the musical comedy, ''Merry, Merry'', in 1925. He later made his first dramatic role in 1932, playing [[press agent]] Owen O'Malley in the original production of [[Ben Hecht]] and [[Charles MacArthur]]'s ''[[Twentieth Century (play)|Twentieth Century]]''. He continued to be a dramatic actor at various locales until 1933.<ref>{{cite web|title=William Frawley|work=Famous Burlington Citizens|publisher=Burlington by the Book|url=http://www.burlingtonbythebook.com/williamfrawley.html|accessdate=2007-06-14}}</ref>
In 1916, Frawley had appeared in two [[short subject]] [[silent films]]. He performed subsequently in three other short films, but he had not decided to develop a cinematic career until 1933, beginning with short comedy films and the feature musical ''[[Moonlight and Pretzels]]'' ([[Universal Studios]], 1933). He relocated to Los Angeles, where he signed a seven-year contract with [[Paramount Pictures]].
Finding much work as a [[character actor]], he had roles in many different [[genre]]s of films — [[comedy film|comedies]], [[drama film|dramas]], [[musical film|musicals]], [[western film|Westerns]], and [[romantic film|romances]]. He appeared in ''[[Miracle on 34th Street]]'' (1947), portraying Judge Harper's political adviser, who warns his client in great detail of the dire political consequences if he rules that there is no [[Santa Claus]].<ref name="imdb"/> Some of his other memorable film roles were as the baseball manager in [[Joe E. Brown (comedian)|Joe E. Brown]]'s ''[[Alibi Ike]]'' (1935), as the wedding host in [[Charlie Chaplin]]'s ''[[Monsieur Verdoux]]'' (1947), and as a hard-nosed insurance investigator in ''My Home in San Antone'', with [[Roy Acuff]] and [[Lloyd Corrigan]].<ref name="imdb"/>
==Television== ===''I Love Lucy''=== [[File:I Love Lucy Cast.JPG|thumb|The ''I Love Lucy'' cast (clockwise): William Frawley, [[Desi Arnaz]], [[Lucille Ball]], [[Vivian Vance]] ]] By 1951, the 64-year-old Frawley had appeared in over 100 movies, but was starting to find film role offers becoming fewer. When he heard that [[Desi Arnaz]] and [[Lucille Ball]] were casting a new television situation comedy, he applied eagerly to play the role of the cantankerous, miserly landlord Fred Mertz.{{cn|date=March 2018}}
One evening he telephoned Lucille Ball, asking her what his chances were. Ball was surprised to hear from him — a man she barely knew. Both Ball and Arnaz agreed it would be great to have Frawley, a motion picture veteran, appear as Fred Mertz. Less enthusiastic were [[CBS]] executives, who warned of Frawley's frequent drinking and instability. Arnaz warned Frawley about the network's concerns, telling him that if he was late to work, arrived [[drunk]], or was unable to perform because of something other than legitimate illness more than once, he would be written out of the show. A slightly different version of this conversation holds that Arnaz contacted the other actor and told Frawley he would get three chances. The first screw-up would be tolerated, the second would result in a severe reprimand, and the third would result in his being fired. Contrary to the network's concerns, Frawley never arrived at work drunk, and mastered his lines after only one reading. Arnaz eventually became one of Frawley's few close friends.{{cn|date=March 2018}}
''[[I Love Lucy]]'' debuted October 15, 1951, on CBS, and was a huge success. The series was broadcast for six years as half-hour episodes, later changing to hour-long [[television special|specials]] from 1957-60 titled ''[[The Lucy-Desi Comedy Hour|The Lucille Ball-Desi Arnaz Show]]'' (later retitled ''The Lucy-Desi Comedy Hour'').<ref name="imdb">{{IMDb name|0292433}}</ref>
[[Vivian Vance]] played [[Ethel Mertz]], Frawley’s on-screen wife. Although the two actors worked well together, they greatly disliked each other. Most attribute their mutual hatred to Vance's vocal resentment of having to play wife to a man 22 years her senior. Frawley reportedly overheard Vance complaining; he took offense and never forgave her. "She's one of the finest girls to come out of Kansas", he once observed, "But I often wish she'd go back there."<ref>{{cite web|author=Jacob M. Appel|title=William Frawley|publisher=St. James Encyclopedia of Popular Culture|year=2002|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_g1epc/is_bio/ai_2419200426|accessdate=2007-06-14}}</ref>
An avid [[New York Yankees]] [[baseball]] fan, Frawley had it written into his ''I Love Lucy'' contract that he did not have to work during the [[World Series]] if the Yankees were playing. The Yankees were in every World Series during that time except for 1954 and 1959. He did not appear in two episodes of the show as a result.<ref>{{cite web|title=Biography for William Frawley|publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies|TCM]] Movie Database|url=http://www.tcmdb.com/participant/participant.jsp?participantId=65571%7c155602&afiPersonalNameId=null|accessdate=2007-06-15}}</ref>
For his work on the show, Frawley was [[Emmy Award|Emmy]]-nominated five consecutive times (1953-1957) for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a comedy series. In 1957, at the end of ''I Love Lucy'', Ball and Arnaz gave Frawley and Vance the opportunity to have their own ''Fred and Ethel'' [[television spin-off|spin-off series]] for [[Desilu Studios]]. Despite his animosity towards her, Frawley saw a lucrative opportunity and accepted. Vance declined, having no desire to work with Frawley again and also feeling that Ethel and Fred would be unsuccessful without the Ricardos.<ref>{{cite web|author=Libby Pelham|title=I Really Love Lucy|work=Popular Culture Blog|publisher=families.com|date=March 25, 2006|url=http://popular-culture.families.com/blog/i-really-love-lucy|accessdate=2007-06-15}}</ref>
===''My Three Sons''=== [[File:William Frawley This Is Your Life 1961.JPG|thumb|upright=1|While appearing on ''My Three Sons'', Frawley was the subject of ''[[This Is Your Life]]'' in January 1961. He received a lifetime baseball pass from the Angels' [[Fred Haney]]. [[Fred MacMurray]] also was part of the show.]] Frawley next joined the cast of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] (later CBS) situation comedy ''[[My Three Sons]]'', playing live-in grandfather and housekeeper Michael Francis "Bub" O'Casey beginning in 1960. Featuring [[Fred MacMurray]], the series was about a [[widower]] raising his three sons. Frawley was originally slated to be the series lead before MacMurray joined the cast, relegating Frawley to supporting player. [[File:1962 My Three Sons.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Clockwise from left: William Frawley, [[Tim Considine]], [[Fred MacMurray]], [[Don Grady]], and [[Stanley Livingston]] on ''[[My Three Sons]]'' (1962)]] Frawley reportedly never felt comfortable with the out-of-sequence filming method used for ''My Three Sons'' after doing ''I Love Lucy'' in sequence for years. Each [[television season|season]] was arranged so that main actor Fred MacMurray could film all of his scenes during two separate intensive blocks of filming for a total of 65 working days on the set; Frawley and the other actors worked around the absent MacMurray for the remainder of the year's production schedule. By the mid-1960s, alcohol and old age finally took their toll, and Frawley began forgetting his lines. By the show's fifth season, Frawley was in such ill health that he couldn't pass the studio's annual health insurance exam and was let go from the program and replaced by [[William Demarest]], who played the role of Bub's brother, Uncle Charley, who moved in to keep house and take care of the family in Bub's absence.<ref name=":0"/>
==Personal life== In 1914, Frawley married fellow vaudevillian Edna Louise Broedt. They developed an act, "Frawley and Louise", which they performed all across the country. Their act was described as "light comedy, with singing, dancing, and patter." The couple [[Legal separation|separated]] in 1921 (later divorcing in 1927). They had no children. His brother Paul Frawley (1889–1973) also was an actor on Broadway with relatively few appearances in motion pictures.<ref>[http://ibdb.com/person.php?id=41227 Paul Frawley profile], IBDb.com; accessed March 17, 2018.</ref>
Frawley had a reputation for being cantankerous and difficult, likely exacerbated by a drinking problem. In 1928, he was fired from the Broadway show ''That's My Baby'' for punching actor [[Clifton Webb]] in the nose.<ref name=":0"/>
==Final years and death== Frawley made two television appearances the year before his death. His appearance on the [[panel show]] ''[[I've Got a Secret]]'' on May 3, 1965, consisted of contestants guessing Frawley's "secret," which was that he was the first performer ever to sing "[[My Melancholy Baby]]," in 1912.<ref>[http://carsonscrafts.com/igas/igas_1965.htm#5-3 "''I've Got a Secret'' Episode Guide",] "Week 673, 5/3/65". Carson & Company Wordsmiths, 2009. Retrieved June 2, 2017.</ref> He had performed that song previously on television, as Fred Mertz, in the 1958 episode "Lucy Goes to Sun Valley" on the ''Lucy-Desi Comedy Hour''.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Lucy Goes to Sun Valley |episodelink=List_of_The_Lucy–Desi_Comedy_Hour_episodes#The_Lucy.E2.80.93Desi_Comedy_Hour_episodes |url= |accessdate= 2013-03-08 |series= [[Lucy-Desi Comedy Hour]] |serieslink= |credits= [[Madelyn Pugh]], [[Bob Carroll, Jr.]], [[Bob Schiller]], [[Bob Weiskopf]] |network= CBS |station= |city= |airdate= 1958-04-14 |began= |ended= |season= 7 |seriesno= |number= 5 |minutes= 30:02 |transcript= |transcripturl= |quote= |language=}}</ref>
Frawley's final on-camera performance was on October 25, 1965, with a brief [[cameo appearance]] in Lucille Ball's second television sitcom ''[[The Lucy Show]]'' in the episode "Lucy and the Countess Have a Horse Guest". Frawley plays a horse trainer and Lucy comments: "You know, he reminds me of someone I used to know." (Vivian Vance, who by then had left ''The Lucy Show'' except for an occasional guest appearance, does not appear in that episode.)<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0637473/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_1 ''The Lucy Show''] - "Lucy and The Countess Have a Horse Guest" at IMDb</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ez_zZ4UnRvw William Frawley's Last TV appearance] on YouTube</ref>
[[File:William Frawley Star HWF.JPG|thumb|upright|Star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] at 6322 Hollywood Blvd.]]
Frawley died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] on March 3, 1966, in Hollywood at the age of 79.<ref name=starwalk>{{cite web| first=Dick| last=Main| date=March 4, 1966| url=http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/william-frawley/| title=William Frawley| work=[[Los Angeles Times]]| access-date=2017-08-22}}</ref> Arnaz, [[Fred MacMurray]], and ''My Three Sons'' executive producer [[Don Fedderson]] were pallbearers at his funeral.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
Lucille Ball said: "I've lost one of my dearest friends and show business has lost one of the greatest character actors of all time. Those of us who knew him and loved him will miss him."<ref>{{cite web |title=William Frawley |publisher=LucySong.com| |url=http://www.lucysong.com/William/william.html |accessdate=2007-06-14}}</ref>
===Legacy=== William Frawley is buried in the [[San Fernando Mission Cemetery]] in [[Mission Hills, Los Angeles, California|Mission Hills, Los Angeles]]. For his achievements in the field of motion pictures, he was awarded a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]], at 6322 [[Hollywood Boulevard|Hollywood Blvd]] on February 8, 1960.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.walkoffame.com/william-frawley| title=William Frawley {{!}} Hollywood Walk of Fame| website=www.walkoffame.com| access-date=2016-06-26}}</ref><ref name=starwalk/> He is memorialized as well in the [[Lucille Ball-Desi Arnaz Center]] in [[Jamestown, New York]], which also contains his "Hippity-Hoppity" (frog) costume from an episode of ''I Love Lucy''. Both Frawley and Vivian Vance were inducted into the [[Television Academy Hall of Fame]] in March 2012.
The story of how Frawley was hired to play "Fred Mertz" in [[I Love Lucy]] is told in ''I Love Lucy: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Sitcom'', a comedy which will have its world premiere in Los Angeles on July 12-15, 2018. The play, from Gregg Oppenheimer (son of I Love Lucy creator-producer-head writer [[Jess Oppenheimer]]), will be recorded in front of a live audience for radio broadcast and online distribution. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/the-behind-the-scenes-story-of-beloved-sitcom-i-love-lucy-heads-to-the-stage|title=The Behind-the-Scenes Story of Beloved Sitcom ''I Love Lucy'' Heads to the Stage|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|date=July 6, 2017|work=Playbill|accessdate=April 5, 2018}}</ref>
